LTTextBox.text: In  comparative  terms,  the  sequence  exposed  within  the  Junction  South  area  is
considered to be a continuation of the better exposed and established sequence of the
Kambalda  Domain  sequence,  as  depicted  in  Table  1.  The  sequence  here  is  however
attenuated, and probably represents a depositional environment where sediment influx
outweighs the contribution from volcanic sources:
the foot wall Lunnon (Lower) Basalt is not widely exposed within the tenement
package, so that
the (thin) komatiitic unit represents the local base to the sequence here;
in the Kambalda stratigraphic column, the unit above the ultramafics comprises
high  magnesian  basalts  and  is  considered  to  be  the  Devon  Consols  Basalt
equivalent and this in turn is overlain by sediments (Black Flag and /  or Kapai
equivalent?) and then felsic volcanics and derived sedimentary rocks.
•  within the Junction South tenement package, the mafic volcanic may or may not
be  present  above  the  ultramafic  –  it  is  clear  that  in  some  areas,  sediments
(Kapai?) sit in direct contact with the ultramafic (Equinox mapping, 2005, P Fey),
and then the monotonous sequence of Black Flag sediments caps this unit.
